question.title: Is there any way to achieve multi-line text that starts in the center and is justified in Java?
question.body:
String sentence = "Hello world, this is a sentence";
JPanel displayPanel = new JPanel(new GridLayout());
JTextArea sentenceArea = new JTextArea(sentence);
sentenceArea.setFont(new Font("Arial", Font.PLAIN, fontSize));
sentenceArea.setLineWrap(true);
sentenceArea.setWrapStyleWord(true); 
sentenceArea.setEditable(false);  
this.displayPanel.add(new JScrollPane(sentenceArea));

I've tried JTextArea, JTextPane and JLabel with no luck.

answers.body:
Using JLabel and HTML

import javax.swing.BorderFactory;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JLabel;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.WindowConstants;

public class HtmLabel {
    int answer;

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame();
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(WindowConstants.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        JLabel label = new JLabel("<html><div align=\"center\" style=\"text-align: justify;\">"
                + "George Best<br/>Manchester United<br/>Northern Ireland");
        JPanel panel = new JPanel();
        panel.setBorder(BorderFactory.createEmptyBorder(30, 30, 30, 30));
        panel.add(label);
        frame.add(panel);
        frame.pack();
        frame.setLocationByPlatform(true);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }
}

        String[] initStyles = { "bold", "justified" };
        JTextPane textPane = new JTextPane();
        textPane.setPreferredSize(new Dimension(270,550));
        StyledDocument doc = textPane.getStyledDocument();
        addStylesToDocument(doc);
        try {
            for ( int i = 0; i < initString.length; i++ ) {
                int pos = doc.getLength();
                doc.insertString(pos, initString[i],
                        doc.getStyle(initStyles[i]));
                if(initStyles[i].equals("justified")) {
                    Style logicalStyle = doc.getLogicalStyle(pos);
                    doc.setParagraphAttributes(pos, initString[i].length(),
                            justified, false);
                    doc.setLogicalStyle(pos, logicalStyle);
                }
            }
        } catch(BadLocationException ble) {
            System.out.println("bad location: " + ble.getMessage());
        }
        return textPane;
    }

    public void addStylesToDocument(StyledDocument doc) {
        Style defaultStyle = StyleContext.getDefaultStyleContext()
                .getStyle(StyleContext.DEFAULT_STYLE);
        Style regular = doc.addStyle("regular", defaultStyle);
        StyleConstants.setFontFamily(defaultStyle, "Serif");
        StyleConstants.setFontSize(regular, 12);
        bold = doc.addStyle("bold", regular);
        StyleConstants.setBold(bold, true);
        StyleConstants.setForeground(bold, new Color(90,0,90));
        StyleConstants.setAlignment(bold, StyleConstants.ALIGN_LEFT);
        justified = doc.addStyle("justified", regular);
        StyleConstants.setAlignment(justified, StyleConstants.ALIGN_JUSTIFIED);
        StyleConstants.setForeground(justified, new Color(90,0,90));
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        StyleTest test = new StyleTest();
        JFrame f = new JFrame();
        f.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        f.getContentPane().add(new JScrollPane(test.getTextPane()));
        f.setSize(400,400);
        f.setLocation(200,200);
        f.setVisible(true);
    }
}

The bold section will be normal flow. The 2nd non-bold section will be justified and you can see the difference on the edges of the pane.

question_comments.body: Did the trick, thanks a lot

start from the center of the panel and "expand" as it gets bigger, equally distributing the words on each line - I gave you a link to an example above. That is the text starts on the top line of the text pane and it will wrap if necessary and be centered horizontally for each line.
@g00se yeah, that's a better way to put it. Justified text that has margins left, right, top, down
@camickr Not really sure what "starts in the center and is justified" means It probably means "I'd like a margin please" ;)

Not really sure what "starts in the center and is justified" means. what if the text is not fixed - if you want text that automatically wraps you would use a JTextPane and play with the attributes. You already have an example below. Here is another example to play with: stackoverflow.com/a/65176138/131872
